notes.title: Hans Kelsen - The Jurist
notes.content:
Hans Kelsen (1881-1973) was an Austrian jurist and legal philosopher. He is known as one of the most influential legal theorists of the 20th century.

Key Contributions:
• Pure Theory of Law
• Grundnorm (Basic Norm) concept
• Legal positivism
• Constitutional theory

notes.title: Pure Theory of Law - Overview
notes.content:
Kelsen's Pure Theory of Law aims to describe law as it is, not as it ought to be. Key principles:

• Law should be studied as a pure science
• Separation of law from morality, politics, and sociology
• Focus on the formal structure of legal systems
• Law as a system of norms

notes.title: The Grundnorm (Basic Norm)
notes.content:
The Grundnorm is the fundamental norm that gives validity to all other norms in a legal system.

Characteristics:
• It is presupposed, not posited
• It provides the foundation for legal validity
• It explains the unity of the legal system
• It is the ultimate source of legal authority

notes.title: Hierarchy of Norms
notes.content:
Kelsen proposed a hierarchical structure of legal norms:

1. Grundnorm (Basic Norm) - Top
2. Constitution
3. Statutes/Laws
4. Regulations
5. Individual Legal Acts - Bottom

Each level derives its validity from the level above it.

notes.title: Criticism of Pure Theory
notes.content:
Critics argue that:

• Law cannot be completely separated from morality
• The Grundnorm concept is too abstract
• Ignores the social context of law
• Overly formalistic approach
• Difficulty in identifying the Grundnorm in practice
